message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. With a suspected stroke, the next step in management should be a CT head to rule out hemorrhagic stroke before administering any anticoagulant or antiplatelet therapy. Aspirin, CTA head, and MRI brain may be necessary after the CT head is done, depending on the CT results.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is exhibiting signs of a stroke, and the first step in management is usually a non-contrast CT head to rule out a hemorrhage. Aspirin may be given after the diagnosis of ischemic stroke is confirmed. CTA or MRI may be ordered after the initial CT scan.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is showing signs of an acute stroke, and the next best step in management is a CT head to assess for any hemorrhage. Aspirin may be given after the cause of the stroke has been identified. CTA or MRI may be ordered depending on the CT head findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms are suggestive of a stroke, and the next best step in management is a CT scan of the head to evaluate for hemorrhage or ischemia. Aspirin can be considered after a CT scan has ruled out hemorrhage. CTA or MRI can provide further information, but CT is preferred as the initial imaging modality to quickly assess for treatable causes of a stroke.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is exhibiting signs of a possible stroke, so the next best step in management is to perform a CT head to confirm the diagnosis and assess for hemorrhage. Aspirin can be given after the CT scan to begin antiplatelet therapy. CTA or MRI may be necessary later for further evaluation, but a CT scan is the first-line imaging study for acute stroke.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms that suggest a stroke, so a CT head is the next best step in management to confirm the diagnosis and assess for any acute hemorrhage that may affect treatment decisions. Aspirin can be given after the CT head if there is no hemorrhage present. CTA head or MRI brain may be indicated later for more detailed evaluation, but CT head is the initial step.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms consistent with a stroke, with facial asymmetry and weakness on one side. The immediate next step would be a CT head to rule out hemorrhagic stroke before initiating thrombolytic therapy. Aspirin is not the immediate next step in management. CTA head or MRI brain may be considered after a CT head.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of a stroke and a CT head scan is the most appropriate next step in management to evaluate for any structural abnormalities that may be causing his symptoms. Aspirin is not the most immediate next step in management, and CTA or MRI may not be as readily available as a CT head scan in the emergency department.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is showing signs of a stroke with facial asymmetry and weakness in the right upper and lower extremities. The first step in management is a CT head to determine if there is a hemorrhagic stroke. Aspirin can be given after ruling out a hemorrhagic stroke. CTA head and MRI brain can be done after the initial CT scan.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is likely experiencing a stroke, which requires urgent imaging to assess the extent of damage and guide treatment. CT head is the most appropriate initial step to evaluate for hemorrhage or ischemia. Aspirin can be given after CT to prevent further thrombotic events. CTA and MRI may be indicated later for further evaluation.
